Speaker: Mr WHITE
Title: EXPORT OP AUSTRALIAN
text: On the 10th May, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr. Blacklow) asked a question, without notice, regarding a report published in the Sunday Sun of the 7th May, rolating to complaints made by a new arrival in the Commonwealth, Mr Sheridan, to the effect that he had been discourteously treated by customs officers at Fremantle in connection with the examination of his passport. The honourable member for to.ascertain Swan (Mr Gregory) also wrote to mc on the subject. A full report has been obtained from the Collector of Customs at Fremantle, and, in my opinion, it discloses that newspaper account was an exaggeration of what actually occurred. The customs officers are responsible for carrying out the provisions of the Immigration im migration Act. . Act, which prohibits the entry into Australia of any person who is likely to become .a charge upon the public by reason of infirmity of mind or body or insufficiency of means of support. Obviously, officers conld not carry out their duties under the act without personally questioning new arrivals. The substance of Mr. Sheridan's complaint appears to be that he was subjected to an inquisition, which lasted twenty minutes, regarding.his private and financial affairs, and that questions were put to him which had no bearing ou his entry into Australia. He further complained that his wife was subjected to what he termed an " equally close and impertinent examination." Twenty persons were noted by the Prinof cipal Medical Officer for the 'port as so requiring further examination by the customs for the purpose of the Immigration Restriction Act. Mr Sheridan came notice because of his age and defective vision. The ship was not boarded by the customs officer till 7 a.m., and the necessary inquiries were completed shortly after 8 a.m., so that the average time for taken in examining euch of the twenty be persons interviewed was only a few of minutes. The questions put to Mr. Sheridan were of a routine character, and were such as are necessary to satisfy the requirements of the Australian immigration laws. There does not appear to be any good reason to believe that the officer showed any discourtesy in" his examination - This is borne out by the-.' senior officer, who was also in attendance. I am of the opinion that Mr Sheridan's statements, as reported in the press, are exaggerated, and were no doubt duo to his resentment at having to answer any question at all regarding his nnancial position. Mrs Sheridan was not questioned, except the address of her son, who u at present in Australia, but whose address Mr Sheridan could not supply. Customs officers are well aware that passengers are entitled to every courtesy and assistance, aud they endeavour to carry out their the duties in a tactful manner, making due allowance for those passengers who feel aggrieved at being asked personal questions to satisfy the requirements nf the NA FACTORY. As a matter of fact, our smokers were able, only with difficulty, to obtain Sufficient supplies of the local article. A very strong demand was made for tobacco made from Australian leaf. The local tobacco is, undoubtedly, improving in quality. It is well known today that 17s. 4d. per lb. is asked over the counter for imported tobacco. There is, therefore, a very big margin of profit even after substantial - duties have been imposed. The objection to the tariff which the Government is now proposing is that it does not allow a sufficient margin of price to induce smokers to use the local article in preference to the imported article. One good effect which may come out of the action which the manufacturers are taking this year in placing the Australian leaf in store, is that it will mature and thus improve the quality of the tobacco made from it. The local manufacturers have not previously matured Australian leaf to any considerable extent. I am sure that the Australian smoker will suffer no disadvantage through acquiring a taste for Austraprolian tobacco, for it is rapidly improving in quality. Many Australian smokers who think that they are smoking tobacco made from imported leaf are really smoking tobacco made from Australian leaf. Smokers who buy " Havelock Aromatic" tobacco may not have noticed an alteration in the lettering on the packets containing the tobacco. The words " Virginian leaf ", which formerly appeared on the packets, have been removed, the reason being, of course, that Australian leaf is now used. The tobacco industry is in a different category from any other, with the possible exception of the distillation of spirits. Tobacco is a narcotic, and the duty, placed on it is purely a revenue duty. I submit that the Government is entitled to impose a sufficient duty on this article to cause it to yield the amount of revenue obtained from it prior to last year, but under conditions which will not make tobacco any more expensive to our smokers. I challenge honourable members to name any industry that we have built up in this country that can be compared with the tobacco industry. But I give an undertaking that, at all times, I will agree to a raising of the excise duty, as the local industry captures more and more of the Australian market.

Speaker: Sir HENRY GULLETT
Title: SEAT OF GOVERNMEN T
text: Henty) [3.25]. - I cannot refrain from commenting on the remarkable change that has taken place since last year's debate on this item. I think that I may say that the whole tone of this discussion is entirely different from that of last year. The dismal forebodings as to the future, consequent upon the alteration of the duties a year ago, are not nearly so prominent in the present debate. As the Minister, who was responsible for the drastic change made last year, I should like to' acknowledge the almost unanimous, and! even generous, admissiou that that altera : tion has worked out extremely well for the growers, at least so far as last year's crop is concerned. Having been sub-' jected last year to bitter criticism, I much appreciate the admission from all parts of the House that the change was not a disastrous one, but, on the contrary, was highly beneficial. I take a bright view of the future, and, indeed, of the near future, of this industry in the Commonwealth. I believe that the problems and difficulties still confronting it are due entirely to its sudden development, and: are merely incidental to the transitionstage through which it is passing. Two facts stand out clearly. The first is that the Commonwealth can, and will, produce all of its requirements " of tobacco, and, in my it will produce them at a very early date. The honourable member for Indi (Mr Hutchinson) in an admirable, well informed and courageous speech, last night estimated that it would take the growers about ten years to capture the Australian market. Personally, I consider that if they watch their business closely, and work well, they will capture about 90 per cent, of the Australian market within the next four years at most. . Of course, it will always be necessary to import a quantity of tobacco for blending and flavouring purposes. The next fact that stands out clearly is that the local manufacturers admit that the Australian grower can produce sufficient leaf to meet this country's requirements of tobacco. That is a most significant admission. It was made clear last year that the local manufacturers, and particularly the British-Australasian Tobacco Company, entered into their huge undertaking for the purchase of the Australian crop in the belief that they were buying leaf that would produce a tobacco acceptable to the Australian smoker, and in the sure conviction that the quality of the locally-produced article would progressively improve, and, eventually, take the place of the imported Virginian leaf. If the local industry is to capture the market at an early date, two things are essential. First, there must be still further improvement of the quality of the leaf. Unquestionably, our highest grade leaf is equal to the best Virginian leaf: indeed, the one closely resembles the other. That similarity makes the change-over all the simpler for every one concerned. The first essential is that individual growers shall concentrate on the production of leaf of the highest possible quality. The second requirement is a complete overhaul of the organization controlling the industry. The Australian tobacco manufacturing companies undertook to 7,250,000 lb. of leaf. Of that quantity the British-Australasian Tobacco Company agreed to buy 6,000,000 lb., but. instead, it bought nearly 8,500,000 lb. of leaf at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. Altogether, the various companies purchased between 10,000,000 lb. and Sir Ilenry Gullett. 11,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf, and for opinion, all the leaf of first-class quality they paid the growers. more than 2s. 3d. per lb., the average being 2s. 3d. per lb. With a protection of 3s. per lb., which the present duty gives to them, Australian growers of good bright leaf are assured of a fair price in the future for their output up to a total national production of 20,000,000 lb. per-. annum. But for the grower of dark leaf I see nothing ahead but disaster. Any attempt to encourage the growth of such leaf is absolute madness. In my opinion, any honourable member who encourages growers to cultivate tobacco on rich river flats, which are likely to produce only dark and heavy leaf, is most unwise, and, indeed, unkind. As I have said, I predict that within three or four years Australia will produce from 18,000,000 lb. to 20,000,000 lb. of tobacco leaf, equal in quality to sound Virginian leaf. Any attempt to force either the manufacturers of tobacco, or the smokers of tobacco, to accept heavy dark leaf, would be most unwise. The Government should make it clear to the growers of dark leaf that there is no prospect but disaster ahead of them. The tobacco-growing industry in Australia is poorly organized. There has been too much politics and not enough of business methods in it. There has been too great a desire to send deputations to Canberra in order to secure votes for the industry. Those concerned would have served the industry better had they set themselves to improve the industry from within, and to establish it on a sound basis. The inefficiency of the organization was shown clearly in its estimate of last year's crop. In March last year, when the tobacco harvest season was approaching, a deputation which waited on the Prime Minister (Mr Lyons) and myself stated that the organization expected a total production of 5,000,000 lb. of tobacco leaf. Later, when the crop proved to have been a much heavier one, purchase a representative of the growers endeavoured to explain the error by saying that the deputation had meant that the leaf would be 5,000,000 lb., and that excise would be paid on a greater quantity. The growers' officials informed us that the crop would certainly not exceed 7,000,000 lb.; but when it was gathered it was found to be about double that quantity. The estimate of that deputation placed the Government in an exceedingly difficult position. It was almost impossible to enter into negotiations with the manufacturers on a satisfactory basis, because of the uncertainty regarding the amount of the crop which would be handled. We are now told^that this year's crop will not exceed 6,000,000 lb. I do not know what that estimate is worth. The position of the present Minister must be exceedingly difficult, because of the absence of anything like exact information. In order to obtain a more reliable estimate of last year's crop than was presented - to me by the deputation, I obtained an officer from the Development Branch of the Prime Minister's Department, and instructed him to proceed to the various tobacco-growing districts in order to make an estimate of the crop. He did so, and the result was most satisfactory. The estimate of the organization representing the growers was of no value whatever. The honourable member for Forrest  forebodings today regarding the future of this industry as he was twelve months ago. The honourable gentleman contrasted the attitude of the Australian Government towards the tobacco-growing industry with that of the Government of the TJnited States of America. He said that in the United States of America the growers of tobacco were subsidized by means of a bounty on the tobacco they produced, whereas the industry in Australia was loaded with an excise duty of 4s. 6d. per lb. I remind the honourable member that last year the American tobacco-grower received only 6d. per lb. on the ground for his leaf, whereas Australian growers of all tobacco, other than rubbish, were paid an average of 2s. 3d. per lb. for their crop, and in the previous year, 3s. per lb. Whatever the Commonwealth Government may, or may not, be doing to assist the tobacco-growing industry, the Australian smoker certainly subsidizes the growers of tobacco to the extent of from 100 per cent, to 150 per cent, of the value of his leaf. Speaking of the great value of the industry to Australia, the honourable member for New England (Mr Thomjjson) said that last year's crop was worth £1,250,000. That, possibly, was the cost to Australian smokers of tobacco, but the leaf they consumed could have been importedfor about £500,000, including exchange and primage duty. It will therefore be seen that Australian smokers of tobacco paid to the local growers of the leaf a bounty of about £750,000 in respect of last year's crop. Australian tobacco-growers receive from 100 per cent, to 200 per cent, more for their leaf than is paid to any other tobacco-gro wers in the world. I wish this industry well. Its pioneers are deserving of praise for the way in which they have persevered in order to improve the standard-particularl y during the past three or four years. I speak not of the new men who have rushed into' grow tobacco on unsuitable land while the going was good, but of those who have been longer in the industry. To these pioneers Australia owes a debt of gratitude. The subject of revenue has again cropped up. I do not wish to transgress the Standing Orders, but it is difficult to dissociate a discussion of the duty from references to excise or revenue. If I may quote a precedent last year, the honourable member for Darwin (Mr Bell), as Chairman of Committees, allowed the debate to range over the whole subject. It has been claimed that the forecast made by the Government last year as to the revenue which would result from the duty on tobacco has been falsified by results. It is true that the Government then budgeted for something like £6,500,000 from this source, and that it now appears that the amount will be exceeded by approximately £600,000. The explanation is aperfectly simple one, and was given by the honourable member for Indi (Mr Hutchinson) in his excellent speech last night. When the Government came to make its agreement with the Australian tobacco manufacturers, who, with the growers' organizations, had not the vaguest idea of the growers' crop anticijiatious, it was found that the manufacturers had entered into contracts and actually paid for something like 9,000,000 lb. of Virginian leaf, which, as an act of common justice the Government gave the manufacturers permission to import. That leaf has been brought into Australia within the past year, and a duty of 3? per lb. has been paid upon it ; I have no doubt, that: ahadditional 4s. 6d. per lb. excise has. been paid on portion of it - To - .those circumstances only is the swollen . revenue- - for -.the ;year attributable. I doubt that 'Jthe imports of tobacco from the TJnited States of America will exceed 2,0.00,000 or 3,000,000 lb. during the coming, year.; so. that a heavy shrinkage in the revenue from that source must be expected. My reply to the contention of the honourable member for Forrest is that he should take not only one year, but an average over two or three years, when estimating what would have been the result had the Government not entered into its agreement with the manufacturers. Assuming that last year's crop amounted to 12,000,000 lb., it would have represented a total loss of revenue to the Government of £3,000,000, at the old duty of 5s. 2d. per lb., which, while it would not have occurred in any one twelve months, would have been suffered during the Government's period of office. It was that which was the great impelling force behind the Government's action. . In conclusion, if I may be so vain, I repeat a statement that I made a year ago; I look forward keenly to the development of the tobacco industry in Australia, and I am sure that that is the attitude of the Government. that desire is qualified'by the condition that the tobacco industry must continue to contribute heavily to the revenue of the country. The industry is of incomparably greater importance to the Government of the country as a revenue producer than it is to our tobacco-growers as a source of income. Last year's crop added to the wealth of growers approximately £500,000, while as a revenue producer tobacco has contributed about £7,000,000 to the exchequer. We cannot afford, by a change, either of excise or duty, materially to affect that position. The present rate of duty is 3s. per lb, and the excise 4s. 6d. per lb. There is a proposal to reduce the rate of excise on Australian leaf in some way. How that is to be done only on Australian loaf I do not know, and I leave the problem to wiser and shrewder heads than mine. It is insisted by the honourable member for New England, and every Sir Henry Gullett. other honourable member agrees with him, that Australian leaf is now approximately asgood as the best importedleaf, and will ultimately - take the place of . the latter; also, that there is no limit to .the quantity of first-class leaf that can be grown in Australia. Accepting that contention, ' it is surely no hardship to the growers if our leaf has to carry an excise duty of 4s.'6d. per lb., when the American leaf, which finds a ready consumption in Australia, bears a total impost of 7s. Cd. per lb. Those who urge the case of the growers cannot have it both ways. If the Australian leaf - is as good as the American leaf, it should readily carry an equal impost. It is being let off lightly by being subjected to an impost of 3s. per lb. less than the American; also, that amount' is lost to the Treasury. The Australian grower has fallen on his feet; the market is his if he grows good leaf, and there should be no objection to his product carrying an excise of 4s. 6d. per lb.

I hope that in view of the misunderstandings and difficulties which have arisen during the course of this debate, the Government will accept the amendment of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Riordan) to postpone' the item, at least for a few days until we can decide whether it is possible to adopt some other policy which will be beneficial to the growers, and put a stop to the turmoil which is now developing in the industry, at the same time assisting the Government to extricate itself from a tight corner.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN

text: Kennedy) [4.17] - I wish to point out to the members of the Country party and other honourable members representing tobacco-growing areas that if they carry this item as it stands, in the hope of altering the excise duty when' the excise schedule is before the committee, I am afraid that any opportunity to assist the growers and those engaged in the tobacco industry will be lost to them. My amendment aims at the restoration of the. margin of protection established by the Scullin Government, which was an import duty of 5s. 2d. per lb., and an excise duty in respect of tobacco manufactured from both Australian and foreign leaf. As I cannot .move for an increase of duty because of the fact that any alteration of the rates would affect the revenue of the Common. wealth, I have moved that the item be postponed. Speaker: Mr THOBBY
Title: SEAT OF GOVERNMEN T
text: An amendment reduce the excise duty could be moved in committee. ME. RIORDAN - It could not. If we pass this item as it stands, there will be no opportunity given to us to move for a reduction of excise duty of, say, Is. 6d. per lb., the consequent loss in revenue to be . made up by an increase of. the import duty. Yesterday the honourable  interjection, indicated that he proposed to support the amendment. Since then the Government, realizing that it was likely to be defeated on this item, has evidently approached the Country party for support, because the Acting Leader of that party has now adopted an attitude quite different from that of one. of his own colleagues who seconded the amendment, and who was chairman of the select committee which inquired into the tobacco industry. The honourable member for Gippsland has left his colleague high and dry. Last night the Postmaster-General  true ring about the amendment and the arguments of those who were advocating that additional protection should be given to the industry. Since this Government has been in office the members of the Labour party' and other honourable members have been continually fighting on behalf of the tobacco-growers. Protests have . been forwarded to the Minister for Trade and Customs, and deputations have waited upon the Prime Minister, the previous Minister for Trade and Customs, and the present Minister. Telegrams have been sent to practically every honourable member, asking him to make a stand in the interests of the tobacco-growers. It has been stated that the growers are quite content with the present rate of duty. That statement is not correct. The growers must have some 'reason for complaint, otherwise they would not go to the expense of sending delegations to Canberra. I say definitely that the growers are not satisfied with the existing tariff protection. The Minister has stated that the Mareeba growers were opposed to the renewal of last year's agreement, but it is evident that the secretary of the Mareeba Growers Association, who is an accountant, and its president, who is an agent, have been fed by the manufacturers with to their propaganda in opposition to a renewal of the agreement under which they guaranteed to purchase up to 8,000,000 lb. of leaf at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. There was nothing wrong with that agreement, and no one had any complaint to make about it. The manufacturers honoured it, because they bought 10,000,000 lb. of leaf at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. They purchased 2,000,000 lb. of leaf over and above the quantity that they undertook to buy. Some of that tobacco sold in and around Mareeba brought up to 3s. 9d. per lb. When visiting a few of the factories in the capital cities, I noticed that some of the tobacco which the manufacturers had purchased had been badly banded and packed, and was not really worth the price paid for it. The agreement did. not compel the manufacturers to buy that class of tobacco, but, nevertheless, they honoured the agreement. The restriction of imports gave security to the .growers, but since the termination of the agreement, the manufacturers have suddenly discovered that a disease known as " spotty leaf " has broken out in North Queensland. While the agreement was in existence, the manufacturers tried to persuade the Mareeba growers that there was no need to renew it, because, in any case, they would buy the whole of the tobacco leaf at favourable prices. They also contended that tobacco leaf was being grown in unsuitable areas. I admit that some persons began to grow tobacco in unsuitable areas, but, from the outset, their efforts were doomed to failure. That took place even in Queensland. In that State, the growers have had the benefit of instruction from agricultural experts. The Oouncil for Scientific and Industrial Research has established an experimental station at Mareeba, where instruction can be obtained in the cultivation of tobacco leaf, and the selection of land and seed. The growers in that district are producing a leaf which I am satisfied can be marketed Much of the work in the tobacco growing industry is seasonal, and one great advantage is that it provides employment in Queensland during the slack period of the sugar industry, which is between December April. This industry is deserving of protection for that reason alone. The Minister said that he had received from atrade source the information that spotty leaf was prevalent in the Mareeba district. It is a peculiar circumstance that the honourable gentleman should rely on information from a trade source when the Commonwealth has in Mareeba a tobacco expert who could supply, within an hour or an hour and a half, any information that it desired. A reliable informant would be Mr Howell, who is in charge of the experimental station at Mareeba. The honourable member for Henty (Sir Henry Gullett) said that he was pleased that the hostility displayed towards the proposals of the Government was not so marked on the present occasion as when he was Minister for Trade and Customs. T assure him that it is quite as great. It, should be greater, because, although he was responsible for the reduction of the duty, he at least took steps to protect the industry during the marketing of last season's crop, by limiting imports and securing a price for the growers. The present Minister says that the companies undertake to purchase this year all the bright leaf produced and Mahogany No. 2 to the extent of the quantity of dark tobacco manufactured by them this year. Prom 25 per cent, to 30 per cent, of the - ii'op will be light leaf - I do not know Mr Riordan. what quantity of dark leaf was handled by the company. Assuming, however, that its purchases last year totalled 12,000,000 lb., if they take only the light leaf this year the quantity disposed of by the growers will be not greater than 4,000,000 lb. Therefore, unless the effect of the Government's policy has been to lessen the production by '8,000,000 lb. on last year's figures, the balance will be left without a market, and there is no guarantee that it will be sold. The Minister said that the companies have bought two years ahead. I point out that it is necessary to store Australian tobacco for two years, so that it may mature sufficiently before the manufacturing stage is entered upon. The reason for the failure to have the agreement renewed is and the low price of tobacco in the TJnited States of America. The Australian growers have no guarantee in regard to prices, and cannot be sure that more than a comparatively small proportion of the leaf grown will be purchased. No difficulty will be experienced in marketing the Mareeba crop, because it is a good quality leaf which finds a ready sale at a price about Is. or Is. 3d. per lb. higher than that paid for the leaf produced in other districts. A lighter crop to the acre'is produced, but the quality is that which is demanded by smokers. The honourable member for Henty referred to the subsidy paid by smokers to the growers of tobacco. There is practically no difference between the priceto-day and that which ruled in 1929, before any protection was given to the industry. Up to three or four weeks ago. one could purchase fine cut Champion tobacco in Melbourne for Is. 6d. or Is. 7d. a 2-oz. packet. To-day the imported manufactured tobacco is Is. 9d. a 2-oz. packet. QLD tobacco, which is equal to the imported, can be bought for Is. 9d. a 2-oz. packet in Sydney. The honourable member for Henty says that the smoker pays a subsidy on Australian-grown leaf. Is that not preferable to paying a subsidy on that grown by the .coolie or the negro, who today is receiving 6d. per lb., and who last, year did not get sufficient to defray the cost of the gasoline used in transporting his crop to market. In 1930-31 the Australian crop was less than 2,000,000 lb., and although in that year more, than 3,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf was used in manufacture, compared with less than 1,000,000 lb. in 1928-29, still the great demand for Australian tobacco in 1931 could not be supplied. In addition to a great improvement in quality-a n all important factor - it was comparatively low in price. The import duty was then 5s. 2d. per lb., but the consumer of the local article was able to purchase it for 5s. per lb. less than imported tobacco. No attempt was made to exploit the protection afforded. The excise duty on tobacco then was 2s. 4d. per lb., making the combined duty on imported tobacco 7s. 6d. per IB. The duty on tobacco leaf entering the United Kingdom is 9s. 6d. per lb., and there is no local industry there to protect. The net result of the last alterations made in tobacco duties was to leave the combined duty on imported tobacco unaltered, but to increase the duty on Australian tobacco by 93 per cent; from 2s. 4d. to 4s. 6d. per lb. One immediate result was an increase in the price of Australian tobacco, with a marked decline in the consumption of it. Manufacturers freely admitted that their inability to supply the demand for Australian tobacco in 1931 was due to the limited supplies of local leaf. Growers set out to make up the shortage, but before the first big crop was harvested the duties were drastically altered. The value of the Australian crop in J 929-30 was £92,000, and in 1931-32, well over £1,000,000-som e estimate it as high as £1,250,000. In 1929-30, the value of foreign leaf imported was £1,76S,000, and in 1931-32, £575,000. The beneficial effect to Australia will be seen by comparing these figures. Directly and indirectly, thousands of workers obtained employment who otherwise must have remained on the dole. In 1929-30, only 6 per cent, of the tobacco leaf manufactured locally was grown in Australia. A federal parliamentary select committee, after an exhaustive inquiry into the industry early in 1930, found that the then tariff protection of 3s. per lb. was inadequate. It recommended an increase, and the Government gave it, with the results stated. Towards the end of 1931, the Tariff Board inquired into the industry. No tobacco farms were visited, and only a very small number of growers gave evidence. The board's report proposed " crushing competition." In the report, at page 12, is this amazing statementThe board has already pointed out that the quantity of Australian-grown leaf will continue to increase unless the industry is exposed to crushing competition by the removal of the duty or its reduction to a figure thai will not constitute adequate protection. Growers feel that by leaving the combined duty on imported tobacco unaltered, and increasing the duty on Australian tobacco by 93 per cent., a crushing blow has been dealt to the local industry. They seek a revision of the present duties in such a way as will enable Australian tobacco to be put on the market at a pricewell below that of imported, and in this direction urge a substantial reduction in the excise on Australian tobacco. This would again stimulate the consumption of the local article and the purchase of Australian-grown leaf. A strong deputation waited on the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade and Customs last year, and requested a differential rate of excise-3s . 4d. on Australian tobacco and 5s. 4d. on imported. The request was not granted. There are other alternative schemes which could be considered. One is for a reversion to the 1931 duties, with progressive increases in excise to make good any loss in revenue resulting from a decline in the volume of imports. Another scheme suggested provides for a compromise between the 1931 duties and those now operating as follows:-193 1 duties, import, 5s. 2d.; excise, 2s. 4d.; margin, 5s. 2d.; present duties, import, 3s.; excise, 4s. 6d.; margin, 3s.; suggested duties, import, 4s. 6d.; excise, 3s.; margin, 4s. 6d. The adoption of these suggested rates might be acceptable to all parties. The required, revenue would be forthcoming. The price of imported tobacco would not be increased. The price of Australian tobacco would be lowered, and there would be no administrative difficulty. I have received from E. S. and B. C. Moultou Limited, a letter referring to an exhibit which they staged at the recent Royal Agricultural Show in Sydney. They had as a backcloth to their stand a life-size replica of a sign which depicted Uncle Sam standing behind a gate, on which appeared the words, "US. Customs". Above the figures were printed the ' words, " Would they allow our tobacco into Virginia?" That is a fair question for Australians to ask. l^fegro-grown tobacco is allowed to enter Australia, and, unfortunately, many Australians purchase the imported in preference to their own tobacco, even though the price is the same. Economic circumstances, of course, compel many persons to. buy the cheapest article, no matter where it comes from. Up to date, however, most of our tobaccos have been sold at the same price as that charged for imported tobacco, although the Mareeba tobacco manufactured in Brisbane is 2d. a 2-oz. tin dearer than imported tobacco. Australian tobacco cannot be marketed at a higher price because of the extent of unemployment, rationing, and relief work, which makes it necessary for housewives to watch every penny and to buy in the cheapest market, no matter how strongly imbued they may be with the Australian sentiment. The honourable member for Henty said that there would be a shrinkage in imports this year. I point out that the quantity of foreign leaf imported into Victoria over a period of six months in 1932 was greater than for the. corresponding period in 1931. Imports have been flowing into that State while low prices have existed in the United States of America; the importers have filled their stores and made provision for next year, and the tobacco producer of this country must get along as he may. The honourable member for Henty also made the statement that the combine would be prepared to buy all good leaf. Who is to be the judge whether leaf is good or bad? The grower naturally says that his leaf is good, and the buyer seeks to depreciate the quality so as to obtain it at a lower price. In the last analysis, buyer becomes the) judge, because of circumstances over which the grower has no control. The reason given by the Country party for again sidestepping the issue is, that it can accomplish some measure of reform by means of an excise duty of 4s. 6d. per lb. on foreign-grown tobacco, and .of 3s. per lb. on Australian-grown leaf. Do the Mr Riordan. members of that party really hope to get anything from the Government, or has the Government changed its policy in regard to the excise duty? Last year the then Minister for Trade and Customs said that he did not think it would be possible for the Government to have two different excise duties, one on foreign-grown and the other on , locally-grown leaf. He argued that a new department would be required to police the matter if such a practice were adopted. He referred the question to the Comptroller-General of Customs, whose opinion was that even if it were not impossible to have two different excise duties operating, such a scheme would be extraordinarily difficult and comulicated to administer.' Replying to the deputation which waited upon him at that time, the honourable gentleman saidThe Government was quite prepared, and had so indicated, to see that the full crop ' grown this year of sound marketable tobacco was purchased by' the companies, and it intended to maintain the highest possible price. This would not be left for the companies to decide. If necessary, the Government would put an embargo on as a starting point, and then come to terms with the companies. The Government could take action along those lines today. The Minister, I admit, has the power to keep out imports by means of an embargo. If an embargo were put on-and it is strongly advocated by a number of growers' associationsmuch of the leaf not now regarded by buyers as sound and marketable would quickly become so. Growers desire to know where they stand in regard to the portion of last season's marketable leaf still unsold, and also in regard to the disposal of this year's crop. Although the 1932 Australian crop was-over 12,000,000 lb - som e estimate it as high as 14,000,000 lb - compare d with less than 2,000,000 lb. in 1931, importations of foreign leaf still flow in freely. The Victorian crop in 1932 was five or six times the that of 1931, and still more foreign leaf entered Victoria for the six months ended December, 1932, than for the corresponding period of 1931. In 1930 and 1931 there was a glut of leaf in the United States of America, with rock-bottOm prices prevailing. In 1929, the average landed cost of American bright leaf was Is. 6d. per lb. To-day it is about 6d. per lb. It is considered imperative that drastic restrictions, if not an embargo, should be placed on the importations of this leaf into Australia. Even in America, a move is being made to have an embargo placed on the importation of a type of loaf from Sumatra which is adversely affecting the local product. Australian market assured to local growers, a large sum of money, instead of being sent to America each year for tobacco leaf, will be retained in Australia, providing employment in this country. Contrast America's policy with the attitude of the Sydney Royal Agricultural Society recently towards the Brisbane firm of E. S. and R. C. Moulton Limited, which desired to adverti.se the Australian tobacco industry at the last Sydney show. The following letter, written by the firm mentioned, to the society, is self-explanatory:We desire to bring under your notice the circumstances surrounding an incident that occurred during tlic Royal Agricultural Show in Sydney. As distributors for the Associated Tobacco Manufacturers Proprietary Limited, of Brisbane, who manufacture a high class Australian tobacco, we staged an exhibit in the Industrial Hall ut the Show, and, as a hackcloth to our stand, a life-size replica of the above sign was erected. The sign mentioned was an. illustration of Uncle Sam barring the entrance of Australian tobacco into V i r g in i aThe Royal Agricultural Society took exception to this sign and ordered its removal in the following terms:There is a sign on your stand which, in the opinion of the society, is not in keeping with the standard of commercial and international impartiality we endeavour to maintain. The sign and picture we complain of . . . refers to the entry of Australian tobacco into Virginia, and I must ask you to have same removed or covered in some way.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: SEAT OF GOVERNMEN T
text: Corangamite) [4.48] I am sorry that the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr White) did not see h*is way clear to allow the excise duty to be debated, during the discussion on this item, because I feel sure that the debate on excise will be simply a repetition of this discussion, and will probably occupy some days which could be more profitably devoted to the consideration of other important subjects. Tobacco-growing is a comparatively new industry in Australia, at all events as regards the cultivation of leaf for smoking purposes. But 75 years ago tobacco of a kind was grown in considerable quantities in this country, particularly in Victoria. Cultivation methods in those days were similar to those employed for the production of W it h the maize, potatoes and other agricultural products. B y this I mean that the leaf was grown .in rows 20 inches apart, and 'was horse-hoed. Since attention was not then given to quality, the production was used mainly as a preparation for sheep dip. For many years the belief was general that the improved quality of tobacco leaf could not-be grown in this country. We have found that that is not the case. Whenever any new industry is being established, the practice has been for governments to, as far as possible, give it every assistance by means of bounties or protection through the customs; and it is a fact that many industries which have been assisted in this way have not had a total capital investment that would be represented in the value of one tobacco far m . But, having been promised high, if not prohibitive, duties, to say nothing of the exchange advantage, they were able to make a start, and some have become fair l y well established. I mention theso artificial forms of assistance because I am sure that some, at least, of these new industries, will, when normal times return, go to the wall. Doubtless, the same fate also awaits those tobacco-growers who have not given sufficient attention to the quality of leaf, the climatic conditions and the most improved methods of cultivation. We must not lose sight of the fact that climatic and soil conditions, as well as a number of other important factors, have to be considered if we expect to produce high quality tobacco leaf in this country. Already quite a number of people are growing good tobacco. Unfortunately, quite a number of people are also growing a leaf that is unsuitable for any purpose other than that to which Australian grown tobacco was applied many years ago, namely, as a mixture for sheep dip. Tho difficulties confronting our tobacco growers today had their parallel in the troubles that beset our wheat and wool growers in the initia l stages of their industry. For very many years wheat production in Australia was on an uneconomical basis. Our wheat-farmers did not then appreciate or understand the value of modern practice, nor were'they well advised as to the varieties of "wheat to be grown. Consequently, there were frequent heavy losses in all States, due to smut, rust, take-all, and a number of other plant diseases. Happily those difficulties have been practically overcome, but I remind the committee that success came only when our farmers realized the importance of modern agricultural practice, and the need for cultivating the best varieties of wheat. I venture the opinion that success will come to our tobacco-growing industry through the same avenue, and, I hope, in the near future. It is not too much to expect that, as the result of valuable research work clone by Commonwealth and State experts, blue mould and spotted leaf, which now take heavy toll of the industry, will eventually be eliminated, and that, by the application of proved methods of cultivation, in suitable soils, we shall be able to produce a 'much larger proportion of high grade leaf than is being done now. But it is almost certain that, while the industry is in its initial stages, many men who are producing dark leaf tobacco on unsuitable soils will drop out. It may not be widely known that, by many farmers, tobacco-growing is regarded as a side-line, to enable them, to carry on in this most difficult time of depression. Por the most part these growers are mixed farmers, who are cultivating only a small area as an experiment, and in the circumstances they could hardly hope to be successful. So we may naturally expect that growers who are not devoting the whole of their time to the industry will, in due course, drop out, leaving only the efficient growers in the business. It .seems to me that the success of the industry depends on the production of a high quality leaf. I understand that there are twelve qualities, namely, lemon, grades 1, 2 aud 3; bright mahogany, grades 1 aud 2; mahogany, grades 1, 2 and 3; and dark leaf, grades 1, 2, 3 and 4. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan), when complaining of the refusal of the manufacturers to purchase the crops of some growers, which, the latter declared, consisted of sound, marketable leaf, asked who should be the judge Mr Gibson. when there was a difference of opinion .between buyer and seller. I take'it that the values of the respective grades are determined in much the same way that the value of wool was appraised during the war period, and I assume that only an expert can distinguish between the different grades. I understand that the demand is for lemon leaf, grades 1, 2 and .3, aud for bright mahogany, grades 1 and 2, and that last year the buyers took approximately 10,000,000 lb. of the Australian crop. 1 was also pleased to hear the Minister state today that the manufacturers had agreed to purchase 6,000,000 lb. of this year's crop. As it is estimated that the total production will be only about 6,000,000 lb., the buyers have, annarently, undertaken to purchase the whole of this year's Australian production. But I noted that the Minister stated definitely it was the intention of the manufacturers to purchase only the three grades of lemon leaf and No. 1 grade of bright mahogany. If this is correct, it would appear that No. 2 grade of bright mahogany, the three grades of mahogany, and the four grades of dark leaf, will not be purchased this year, except for the replacement of an unknown quantity of dark tobacco that was used. As the grades which the manufacturers intend to buy this year will represent not more than 40 per cent, of the total crop, it would appear, if the Minister's statement is correct that this year's crop will be only 6,000,000 lb., that the manufacturers will not buy more than 40 per cent, of it. I think I am right in saying that the arrangement made last year for the purchase of the crop was satisfactory to the majority of growers. At all events, it gave satisfaction to those who produced a decent quality of leaf. . Apparently, therefore, those growers whp.se crop is not suited to the requirements of Australian smokers must do what other producers are required to do with their waste cropscrap the unsaleable portion of it. I imagine that many growers, especially those' who are endeavouring to produce tobacco by irrigation methods, and are not turning out the lighter grades which are in demand, will be obliged to face this problem immediately. As this subject was thoroughly thrashed out when last it was before the committee, much of what has been said in .this debate will, I feel sure, be repeated when we are discussing the excise duties. I should like to see a margin between the excise duty on tobacco manufactured from the Australian leaf and tobacco manufactured from the imported leaf. There was, a margin previously, but with the import duty at 3s. per lb., that margin has practically disappeared; with the result, I am told, that sales of . Australian tobacco have fallen off by approximately 40 per cent. I feel sure that, if we could establish a margin between the tobacc.0 manufactured from the Australian leaf and that made from the imported leaf, we should create a greater demand for Australian tobacco. I do not admit that Australian tobacco is inferior to the imported article, and I was interested in a statement made last night by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr E. E. Harrison) who read brief extracts from reports by three experts who expressed the view that Australian tobacco was uniformly of a high standard. That is my view also. When I visited the Mother Country recently, I fouod it impossible to purchase there a tobacco that was. quite suited to my taste. I understand that other Australians have had a similar experience. Consequently most Australians who are ahout to visit - Great Britain take with them a suffi-cient quantity of the Australian tobacco to last them while they are abroad. I . have no doubt also, that people who visit this country from Great Britain or America, for the same reason bring with them supplies of British or American tobacco. This difficulty, if it can be called a difficulty, is due to the fact that tobacco is an acquired taste. It seems to me ' that if we had a variation of, say, 6d. in the price of 2-oz. packets of Australian and foreign tobaccoes, most people would purchase the Australian product, and acquire a taste for it. I , therefore, hope that, when we are discussing the excise - duties, the Government will realise the importance of doing something in this direction, and that the Minister will bring down a proposal to alter the excise rates 6d. up and 6d. down. I am indifferent as to the precise form the amendment should take so long as it is calculated to encourage the local industry, and give a margin of Is. in excise. Not long ago, when the Government altered the duty to permit the introduction of Fijian bananas, an arrangement was made to assist the Queensland banana industry to . the extent of £5,000, the amount which it was estimated the duty on imported bananas wouldrealize. If now the Government will make the small variation which I have suggested in the excise duty on tobacco, it will not affect the revenue in the slightest degree, but will assist the Australian industry very materially. I think every honourable member is anxious to maintain the revenue from the tobacco duties, and, at the same time, assist the local grower. This, I repeat, can be done by the suggested differentiation between the duties to encourage our growers to produce more largely of those grades that are in demand.

Speaker: Mr A GREEN
Title: SEAT OF GOVERNMEN T
text: Kalgoorlie) [4.5S] I agree with the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr Gibson) that if we are to ensure the expansion of the Australian .tobacco-growing industry, it will be necessary to ensure a difference between the market prices for Australian and imported tobaccos. But I ' cannot agree with his suggested alteration of the excise duty. The amendment moved by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Riordan) is, I believe, the only solution of the problem. It is stated, in the circular which has. (been issued to all honourable members, that the net result of the last alteration of the tobacco duties was to ease the position for importers, and to increase the duty on Australian tobacco from 2s. 4d. per lb. to 4s. 6d. per lb - a n increase of 94 per cent. That, in my opinion, was a great mistake. As well as establishing our own secondary industries, we must do everything we can to put our primary industries on a prosperous footing. ' If the wheat-growers, tobacco-planters, and wool-growers continue to receive prices on which they cannot show a profit, the country, despite all its secondary industries, must become bankrupt. That being so, and seeing that the wheat-growing and other long-established industries are not at present paying their way, we should welcome any effort to ensure that the consumption of tobacco in Australia shall be confined as much as possible to Australian-grown leaf. Eor too long has Australia been an open market for the products of the TJnited States of America. For every £1 worth of goods. we sell to that country we buy £7 or £8 worth from there. I have no prejudice against Americans as such. I have lived among them, and know them to be smart business people; but we should cultivate the same spirit towards our industries as they have done towards theirs. As the lionorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) pointed out, there would be very little chance of finding a sale for Australian tobacco in Virginia. We cannot, perhaps, prohibit the importation of American leaf immediately; but we could produce 16,000,000 lb. of the' 23,000,000 lb. consumed annually in Australia, and import for blending purposes the other 7,000,000 lb. to suit the palate of those who cannot be satisfied with anything but American leaf. Taste in tobacco is largely a matter of custom. At one time. I occupied a position in a branch of the Customs Department, and while there met ii man who insisted on importing Mexican cigars. No ordinary Cuban cigars would do him; only Mexican tobacco was, in his opinion, a satisfactory and desirable smoke. In the same way, many sea captains who have traded in the East Indies for years believe that the only cigar worth smoking is the Burmese cheroot, .which is made of dark tobacco. These cheroots can be bought for about i d . each' in Burma, and have a very fine flavour of their own. It is necessary for us to develop all branches of primary production in Australia, and tobacco-growing provides an opportunity of employment for a great many persons. An important feature of the industry is that it is a large employer of labour. A young friend of mine, who recently began growing tobacco in the Ovens Valley, told me that, although he had been used to hard work, he had never previously encountered any jpb which made such demands on his dynamic energy as did tobacco-growing. Unfortunately, a man, after spending his days Mr 'A. Green. and a good part of his nights tending his crop, sometimes loses the whole of it. Tobacco-raising is even more risky than wheat-growing. Tobacco has many natural pests and diseases, and is quickly affected by climatic changes. In the Ovens Valley this year more than half the crop has been swept away by frost. The estimated crop was 4,500,000 lb., and of this 2,500,000 lb. has been lost overnight. Because of this everpresent danger of loss, growers find it necessary to plant a greater acreage than would otherwise be required. Last year. 12,000,000 lb. of Australian tobacco was sold, but over and above that, a considerable quantity was grown which was never marketed, because it had been damaged by blue mould and other pests. It is reasonable to assume that approximately the same acreage has been planted this year as last, yet it is estimated that this year's crop will be only about 6,000,000 lb. I have studied the Tariff Board's report on tobacco, and it seems to me that it has recommended reduced protection, first, because it fears that high duties may encourage a rush of inexperienced growers from other primary industries, and, secondly, because the cessation, of imports may lead to a loss of about £2,000,000 in revenue. ' In the course of its report, the board statesAssuming the total requirements of leaf in Australia to be 20,000,000 lb. annually, and that there would still be approximately 4,000,000 lb. imported for blending purposes, particularly for cigarettes, this would leave a demand for 10,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf annually. Based on a yield of 800 lb. " per acre, it would require 20,000 acres of land to produce the 10,000,000 lb. annually. It will thus be seen that the demand is not very extensive. The loss of revenue previously collected on 10,000,000 lb. of leaf imported under the duty of 3s. per lb. would be approximately £2,000,000. If Australia can provide a market for 16,000,000 lb. of locally-grown leaf, let us produce that quantity, and let us make up the £2,000,000 in revenue from excise duty. It is a remarkable argument that production should be restricted so that we might swell our revenue by the duty paid on imported goods. I was pleased to hear the honourable member for Henty (Sir Henry Gullett) speak this afternoon in that clear incisive fashion with which we are familiar, but he looked at this matter entirely from his own point of view. He seemed to take a great deal of credit to himself for the altered position . of the tobacco-growing industry as a result of the reduction of duties which he proposed. The fact that the import duty has been reduced from 5s. 2d. to 3s. per lb., and. that the excise duty on manufactured tobacco is the same for imported as for Australian leaf, renders it practically impossible for the manufacturers of Australian leaf to put the finished article on the market' at a price which will attract the public. Australians have for so long been used to smoking American tobacco, that the only chance of inducing them to turn over to the local tobacco is to put the latter on the market at prices which will attract them. If imported and Australian tobaccoes are sold at the same price, the unthinking portion of the community will continue to smoke the tobacco to which they have become accustomed. The Government has not taken adequate precautions to safeguard the - growers' interests in regard to the disposal of the present crop. The honourable member for New England (Mr Thompson) said that there was a general belief that the manufacturers proposed to buy only bright mahogany and better grades, which constitute only about 40 per cent, of the crop. To say that the manufacturers are prepared to take 6,000,000 lb. of tobacco

The reply was in the negative. The extent to which mechanization has been carried in the industry is indicated by the following paragraphs which appear at page 27 of the brochure:One large sheet-glass works has only twenty glass workers properly so-called out of a total staff of TOO. The hours of Avork in the glass factories of Belgium are 56 weekly; in those of Czechoslovakia, 48; and in those of France, 48. The conditions in the Belgian factories are bad. This industry is so highly mechanized that out of 700 employees only twenty are skilled mechanics. As the honourable member for Richmond (Mr R. Green) has pointed out, the f.o.b. price of Belgian glass in 1925, before the Australian industry was Jlfr. Hughes. established, was 23s. per 100 sq. f t . , Avhereas it has been quoted recently at 7s. 6d. per 1Q0 sq. f t . This shoAvs the extent to which the Belgian monopoly had been profiting by its Australian trade. The Minister has said that the world has been compelled to recognize that no nation can liA^e for itself alone. That is quite true, but nations must live. The question is: How shall they live? We must find some happy medium between isolation and promiscuity. Britain has been forced to recognize that she must look after her own industries. While other nations have been living for themselves alone, Britain has been living for others. In these days, however, nations must look after themselves. While Britain Avas neglecting this duty her industries were sloAvly sinking to ruin. The only British industry which Avas able to maintain itself through the darkest days of the slump was the motor industry, which Avas sheltered by the Safety of Industries Act. Another question Ave have to ask ourselves is: What effect will the policy of the Government have upon employment and prices on the sheet-glass industry, and on the investment of money in industry generally? Then, too, it is a truism that we must prevent imports rising above a certain level. OtherAvise, we shall be back Avhere we were at the end of 1930, and be compelled to resort to the drastic expedients applied by the Scullin Government to correct the position. It is undeniable that our imports of glass come from a country to which we owe no allegiance whatever. If we were to give to every country what it deserved, we should give very much to Great Britain and absolutely nothing to Belgium. Belgium owes a great deal to us. There are more Australian soldiers lying in graves in. Belgium than there were Belgian soldiers killed in Belgium in the Great War. So I say that Belgium owes a very great deal to us, and we OAve nothing whatever to Belgium. Belgium has control of the glass-making industry, and proposes to keep control of it. The report of the Tariff Board on this industry is not so convincing as we Would desire. The honourable member for Richmond epitomized the report in the concluding words of his speech. He said that three points had to be considered: Can this industry produce the quantity of glass required; is the quality of the glass good, and is the price of the product satisfactory? These are all matters of fact in the determination of which we should exercise our own intelligence. The evidence given before the Tariff Board was from highly prejudiced parties on both sides. The manufacturers and the importers alike were out to present the best case they could for themselves. Looking at the glass manufactured in Australia, I am bound to say, as an uninitiated layman, that it seems to be quite good. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Siley) said that some of the glass in Hotel Canberra supplied by the Belgian combine had a ripple in it, and so was not good. I do not know that the Tariff Board is able to express an expert opinion on this subject. "What more does it know about glass than honourable members do? We have also to consider the effect this change of duty will have upon this industry, aud upon employment generally. The Minister has advanced the board's suggestion that employment in the industry should be rationed; but the general manager of the company has pointed out that that is an absurd proposition. The capacity of this firm is 12,000,000 square feet per annum, and it now has S00,000 square feet in store. To ask it to confine its productionto*1,250,000 square feet per annum is ridiculous. If glass is to be turned out from this factory by its* highly mechanized process at economic prices, the plant must be kept in continuous work throughout the year. Otherwise, it cannot produce cheap glass. It would be better for the factory to close Australian industries. down than for it to limit its production of glass to 1,250,000 feet per annum. We must say either that the factory shall close down, or that the industry shall be protected and encouraged. There can be no half measures. We must determine whether we shall support the Belgian or the Australian industry. The Australian industry is conducted under good conditions and its employees, receive good wages; whereas the Belgian industry is conducted under bad conditions, and its employees receive poor wages. We must further ask ourselves what effect this reduction of duty is likely to have upon the investment of money in industry in this country. We should encourage people to invest their money in industry. The trouble today is that people are afraid to do so. There is plenty of money in the banks, but people will not invest it in industry, because they have no assurance of a fair return. The sum of £300,000 has been invested in the Australian glas3 manufacturing industry, and the industry is being conducted at a high pitch of efficiency. Not even the Tariff Board can quite gainsay that. I have no doubt that before this sheet glas3> manufacturing company began operations in Australia it was given some undertaking that it would be supported. The general manager of the company has made it clear that he'was given to understand that the policy of Australia was that Australian industries would be protected and encouraged. When I was in London, some years ago, a representative that of Babcock and Wilcox Limited, waited on me and asked whether I could give give him an assurance that if his firm established itself in Australia, suitable duties would bo provided to protect it against outside competition. I said that I could not give him that assurance, but I could assure him that the policy of Australia was the encouragement of Australian industries. The result was that the firm began operations in Australia. No doubt the company which embarked upon the manufacture of glass in Australia was given a similar assurance that Australian industries would be protected. But the Government now proposes to change that policy. Such a change of policy will certainly deter people from investing their money in The Minister stated that the Tariff Board had reported that a continuance of the duties that existed at the time it made its report would increase building costs; but the only evidence that I can find in the board's report to support such a statement is that given by Mr Smith, that the extra cost of the glass required for a six-roomed house was only Is. 6d. That trifling possibility surely should not affect us in our judgment. We are confronted with certain facts which, I admit, are capable of many interpretations; but, as I stated this morning at a deputation, we are as capable as the members of the Tariff Board of making a decision on the facts. The board does not deny that this industry is thoroughly efficient and capable of turning out good glass. It is not denied that tha company has turned out or can turn out sufficient glass for our requirements, nor that the Government has some measure of control over an Australian company. If the company were to exploit the public, regulations could be framed to meet the position. No regulations within the legislative ambit of the '('-ommonwealth could prevent exploitation by foreign importers. I u all the circumstances, I can see no reason why the present conditions should not be allowed to continue-at least until the Tariff Board makes its final investigation of this industry. Every investigation of rho board apparently brings it nearer to the point at which it will be able to give the company a clean bill, of health. After its first inquiry the board reported that the Australian product left something to be desired. That can be easily understood. It applies to any industry in the early days of its existence. The board has since reported that, the Australian product has been wonderfully improved. In the circumstances, I suggest that if, is reasonable to ask the Government to hold its hand until the board makes the investigation that has been promised. I am strongly averse to striking a blow at this industry. It appears to me that we are determining to-night something more . than the fate of this particular enterprise. We are determining whether we shall support Australian or foreign industry. It is not a question of the encouragement of trade between Australia and Great Britain. If it were, I should look at it through different eyes. The question is whether we shall encourage an Australian or a Belgian industry. I have no hesitation in declaring on which side I shall array myself. While I am willing to make many concessions, and to go a long way to help British industry, I am not prepared to go a yard to help Belgian industry, or the industry of any other foreign country. Our clear duty is first to our fellow citizens, next to our kinsmen overseas, and then to the world at large. This being Mr Hughes. so, I propose to register' my vote on behalf of my fellow citizens.

Speaker: Mr FORDE
Title: SEAT OF GOVERNMEN T
text: Capricornia) [10.15] The honourable member for Richmond (Mr R. Green) is to be commended for having taken the trouble to visit the factory of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited. If other members of the Country party would follow his example, and acquaint themselves with - the wonderful development that has taken place in Australian secondary industries, they, too, would be more ready to do justice to them. I am pleased that the Government has decided to extend the embargo against the importation of glass for a period of twelve months without any rationing, so long as the stocks in Australia are sufficient to supply requirements. I do uot think there will be much doubt that adequate supplies will be available. It is estimated that 4,000,000 square feet of sheet glass is stored in the warehouses, whilst the Australian manufacturers have over 1,000,000 square feet in stock, and during the period of the embargo will, be able, if working only half time, to supply at least another 5,000,000 or G,000,000 square feet. These quantities in the aggregate will he sufficient to supply the Australian demand for probably two years. I believe that, as a result of further investigations by the Tariff Board, the Australian manufacturers will bo able to satisfy that body in regard to the quality, supply, and price of their product. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Riley), in whose electorate this efficient factory is located, has read testimonials from representatives of the building trade and the tomato-growers that the quality of Australian sheet glass is all that can be desired. I am particularly impressed by the testimony of Mr. H . E. Ross, representing the Institute of Architects of New South WalesMy examination was quite impartial in that respect, and it was comparative . . . In making this comparison, I would like to say that I regarded the Australian-made gloss, which I investigated in sheets in the workssheets picked at random, and in many cases covered with dust, the accumulation of some weeks-as heing distinctly superior to the average of the not identified imported glass. The manufacturers guarantee the local glass to be equal, if not superior, to the corresponding glasses imported from abroad. At an earlier inquiry by the Tariff Board the representative of the principal British manufacturing company condemned in unmeasured terms the .Fourcault process used by the Australian manufacturers, and said that they would not bo able to produce by this means a glass good enough for this market. This process, which originated in Belgium, was copied by the manufacturers at Pittsburg, TJnited States of America, ancl has .since been adopted by the English company, whose representative in Australia had previously condemned it. The Minister stated to-night that the Australian manufacturers would not lm able to get rid of the large proportion of reject glass in their output, whereas manufacturers abroad had the whole world in which to sell their output. The prices of Belgian and British cheap glasses are, per 100 square feet, 8s. 6d. and 12s. 6d. respectively. If the Minister's contention is correct, how will Great Britain be able to sell its reject glass in competition with the cheaper product of Belgium? The manufacture of glass is becoming highly specialized, and through the adoption of improved methods the proportion of reject glass is steadily declining. As far back as five years ago glass of 70 Der cent. oualit.v was being turned out. A rejection of 20 per cent, would not be considered' phenomenal in glass production generally. The Australian Glass Company-the parent of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited-is to be commended for its enterprise and efficiency. We hear it. condemned as a monopoly, but I would prefer a monopoly which gives employment to Australian people, and over which we can exercise some control, rather than be at the mercy of a foreign organization operating in other parts of the world and able to impose its will on Australia. It is a combine with world-wide ramifications that is resisting the establishment of sheet glass manufacture in the Commonwealth. Pilkington's, who have an absolute monopoly in Great Britain of the manufacture of both sheet and plate glass, are allied with the big Belgian companies; in fact, the English and continental interests are linked, and one at least, of the most powerful American companies is working in conjunction with the Belgian manufacturers. When the Scullin Government was in office it found that the Australian Glass Company could not commence operations with the duties still deferred. Importers were accumulating large stocks of glass from overseas, sufficient to meet Australia's requirements for at least twelve months ahead, and while this continued no market, could be found for the output of any Australian factory. Before the local glass could be sold the accumulated stocks in the warehouses had to be disposed of, and action had to be taken to create conditions under which a market would be possible when local manufacture began. On the 19th June, 1930, the Scullin Government, after satisfying itself that there was sufficient' sheet glass in the country to meet all demands for at. least a year ahead, introduced a tariff proposal, that abolished the deferred provisions and imposed, the full rate of duty recommended by the Tariff Board in 1925, and approved by the Bruce Page Government, but deferred from time to time. The action taken by the Scullin Government was the only means of checking the importations which were maintaining warehouse stocks to such an extent as tp prevent local manufacture. When I was Minister for Trade and Customs this industry gave me a great deal of concern. We were confronted witli the problem of Avide^pread unemployment, ancl as the establishment of this industry presented an opportunity to increase employment, I make no apology for having decided to give preference to Australian capital and labour over manufacturers in other countries. The Australian Glass Company, haA-ing £300,000 of capital to invest, could have undertaken the manufacture of sheet glass in Belgium or Great Britain or some other country where labour is cheap, but it bought the Australian rights in the Fourcault process and proceeded to establish a new enterprise in this country. Having invested its money, it Avas entitled to expect that it would get adequate protection against importations of foreign or even British glass. Now it is employing 240 persons. The representative of the workersat a deputation to the Prime Minister said that he had heen on the dole for twelve months, and that a number of his fellows had been on the dole for two years, but were now in employment. Are we going to continue their employment or to send our orders to overseas manufacturers, who prior to the action taken by the Scullin Government, had been exploiting the Australian market? The factory of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited is admitted by experts to be one of the most up to date in the world, and it is manufacturing plain sheet, opal, figured rolled, milled rolled, roughcast, wired cast, and opalescent glasses. This is not an industry for a small struggling company. It requires the resources of a big organization such as the Australian Glass Company. This parent organization has nine factories-four in New South Wales, two in Victoria, and one in each of the other States, except Tasmania: it has a capital of £2,000,000, is employing 2,400 persons, and will soon be employing 3,000 persons if the protection is continued. Inquiries made by the Trade and Customs Department, when I was Minister, elicited the fact that immediately the increased duties were imposed importing and distributing firms raised their prices by an amount equivalent to the higher duties. Huge stocks had been imported by these firms, and the duty paid thereon was at the nominal rates of 2s. and 4s. per 100 square feet. The difference between the former duties and the increased duties was taken from the pockets of the people by the importers who protest loudly that their hearts bleed for the users of glass. The right honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hughes) said that some encouragement must have been given to the Australian Glass Company to embark upon the manufacture of sheet glass. The Bruce-Page Government, in which  Customs, told this, company that it would refer the matter to the Tariff Board for investigation and report. The matter was referred to the board, and the board recommend-sd deferred duties which the Bruce-Page Government put into ilr. Forde. thetariff schedule, and which were, subsequently, put into operation by the Scullin Government. The fact that the Bruce-Page Government put the deferred duties into the tariff schedule was an earnest to the company of the Government's intentions.

The local company employs Australians, and has plant and equipment capable of supplying the whole of the Australian demand. The importation of window glass by the Australian Glass British, Company has been referred to as an attempt to exploit the Australian public, but any impartial person must admit that the importations were made to enable the company to build up a connection with also clients in glass of a class similar to what it intended to manufacture here. The company did not increase its prices. Any increase that took place was made by the importers, who held large stocks in warehouses in Australia. For a time, the local company was severely criticized for _ not manufacturing glass, but, naturally, it was waiting for a demand for its goods, and that was not likely to eventuate while huge stocks were held in the warehouses. The honourable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) has asked why the Scullin Government . put the deferred duty into operation on the 19th June, 1930,. when, in the ordinary course, it would not have become operative until the 1st August of that year. The stocks in hand at that time were sufficient for twelve months supply, so that when the deferred duties were put into operation, there was no danger whatever of any shortage taking place. text: South Sydney) [10.44] - I quite agree that this item, upon which so many varied opinions'have been expressed, constitutes one of the most difficult problems facing the Government. I have a knowledge of many aspects of the glass industry, and have endeavoured to analyse the position in order to come to a fair decision. I venture to say that most of the troubles of this industry have arisen because of a battle royal which has waged between the local manufacturing interests on the one hand, and the importing and distributing interests on the other; but it is not too late now for them to come together in order that the large amount of money which has been invested in this national industry should be conserved, and some hundreds of Australians kept directly and indirectly in employment. It has been suggested inside this chamber, and I think outside of it, that the local manufacturers have exploited the public. It has been stated that the Australian Glass Manufacturing Company, when an increased duty was mooted, stocked its warehouses with importations and, after the passing of the Scullin Tariff, unloaded its stocks on to the public at greatly enit is hanced prices. That is a most damaging statement, which has undoubtedly inflamed the minds of the public. If any honourable member can bring evidence to prove that commercial immorality of this description has been practised by this firm, I am prepared to withdraw my support of the protection given to the industry. The recently submitted report glass, of the Tariff Board may be regarded as out of date, in view of the considerable progress that has been made in the production of Australian glass during the last six months. In 1925, Parliament decided to give adequate protection to this industry, and, as a consequence, a capital of £300,000 was invested in it. If the report of the Tariff Board is given full effect, the industry will be annihilated, with the result that capital to the extent of £300,000 will be lost, many hundredsof Australians will be thrown out of employment, and the plans and organization for the manufacture of Australian glass, which is the product of Australian brains, and is approved of by the Australian people, "will be rendered abortive. Therefore, the industry is able to produce far in excess of Australian demands. The imposition of the protective duty proposed under the latest tariff, however, will not add materially to the cost. The Australian sheet glass used in a six-roomed cottage would cost only Is. 6d. more than the price charged for imported glass paying the old duties three years ago, when exchange was normal, the additional Is. 6d. being made up by primage duty and exchange on the raw material used in the manufacture of the glass. Until world conditions change, Australia must act in like manner.  - In regard to the duties on sheet glass, I believe that the Government has come to the only possible decision, namely, to accept for the time being the recomthree mendation of the Tariff Board to leave the duty at 2s. British and 4s. general, per 100 feet and to refer the matter back to the board, so that the advice that it tenders may be based on the very latestinformation available. The board evidently felt a difficulty about making a recommendation, because in one paragraph it suggests that the rates now operating, namely, 2s. British , and 4s. general, remain in the schedule for twelve months, and that they be terminated or continued after that period according to whether or not it can be shown that they have been effective.
